Also, why are you asking for low fiber? If you've just started eating higher fiber food, it can take a month or even 2 to get used to digesting high fiber foods. Unless it's because of an illness you have, I'd stick to it and see if it goes away. Your body has to get used to new foods. Also, with increased fiber intake you have to increase water, too.

That would be great if he went vegan! He eats vegetarian at home, and was better at stopping red meat consumption when we decided that a year ago. He also grew up vegetarian and was vegetarian for a few years as an adult.
Unfortunately, I doubt it'd change much if I stopped paying for eating out because of subconscious gender roles and all that junk (I'm F, he's M). Although we've been going to lots of vegan restaurants where I pay for it so he can have a better experience.

He would've gone shopping himself because he's better at picking out fruits than i am. He's great at finding crisp apples, it's amazing.
There is a difference in consumption, though, because he's a procrastinating shopper and it would've taken time for him to buy it. So it's possible that he waited a few days (especially with more [vegan] food in the house). Meaning, he could've eaten 1 package of cottage cheese for the week instead of 2. That reduces dairy consumption.
Plus, our relationship is stable enough where it didn't cause any strain (like I stated in the original post).

I'm in a similar situation. He pays the rent and I do groceries (although during the school year, we're long distance for another year so we both handle our own bills). I also cook waaay more often so it makes more sense that the kitchen is better suited for me. Your suggestion of finding veg options is good but I haven't heard of a good one for cottage cheese. Unfortunately, he still wants milk, yogurt, and cheese, and isn't that much into soy milk.
If you want to try again, try kale chips. Use salt and nutritional yeast to top it. They become super light and crispy!

WRITING.TITLE: how do you split groceries with non-vegan SOs?
WRITING.TEXT: Kind of a specific question. I'm newly vegan, and my SO isn't (although he doesn't purchase any meat while doing groceries). I'm newly vegan so my grocery habits have changed a little (obviously). While I was shopping, I asked if he wanted anything and he asked for cottage cheese. I couldn't buy it for him because I just didn't want to spend my money on that. Is it ok that I just told him to buy it on his own? There was no big argument over this so it didn't cause a strain. I was just wondering what others did in this situation. Is what I did typical or picky? Both?

There's a spectrum of personal details with how intimately you know someone.

You could look into performance anxiety medication, I think one is propranolol. I don't have experience with it but Xanax can cause euphoria and such which you won't get with the former. Also, if you take a low enough dose of Xanax, and stay at that dose, you shouldn't become addicted. I doubt the dr gave you a high dose either since it's hard to function properly at high doses. You can always try it, and know it isn't for you and stop any time.

Oils are good when you're only eating 1400 calories. Coming from someone who underate, they're a godsend because you can hide it in stuff you make instead of having to eat more.
Also, OP, make sure he's counting all of his calories correctly. It's possible that he added extra oil when he was cooking but it's really easy to forget to add that when counting calories.

I would be careful with feeding a wide variety of foods as pets can learn how to be picky! If they don't like a certain food, they may not eat it until they get the food that they like. For instance, I take care of a cat (not mine) who is given raw food and kibble, yet the kibble is yummier for her (in the way fast food is yummy for humans I'm guessing). So, she stopped eating the raw food which is much healthier. When I took care of her, I stopped giving her the kibble all together and she eventually ate the raw. It's a lot to think about but most recipes I see with feeding animals whole foods blend or mush it all so they can't eat around it. I wouldn't assume variety affects dogs like they do humans.

WRITING.TITLE: How would I get this color hair I keep seeing in Japan? (ash blonde, slightly pink/grey undertones?)
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm traveling in Japan right now and I keep seeing this type of hair color. It's a very ash blonde, but there's a sort of pinkiness. Almost a grey-silver-pink. Some photos of what I'm looking for:
[\[1\]](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/aa/aa/ee/aaaaee5c8a6921470e6bc8df6c3be82e.jpg) [\[2\]](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/236x/a9/bb/9e/a9bb9e4d3e8943517e51d045417976d9.jpg)
(I know these are different colors, but I can't really find the specific color nor do I need a specific color).
I'm pretty platinum blonde right now (from dark hair). What products would I use? I usually tone Wella in T-18. My guess right now is leave in Wella T-14 toner for too long, maybe 35-40 mins (dangerous?), with a very very diluted (more diluted than pastel hair) cool pink and maybe Ion in Titanium.
Also, I'm really used to having colors in my hair so I don't really care if I go too purple or pink or whatever. I'm wondering if there's a specific product I can get in the US for this color, too.
Thanks!
Thanks! We're going to Haneda. 12 hours total between check out and the actual flight. We might go to a love hotel for some rest. Thanks for the link!

You have to buy the phones as an upfront cost, and then each device per month is a base rate of $6. Then you add the minutes, text, and data of however much you (and whoever you add) use.
Example of two devices would be:
One time payment of each device (your example of $170) x 2
Monthly payment of $6 per device (so $12 for two devices, etc). If you don't use your phone at all, lets say you're traveling, it'll be $12 total. Say you texted, called, and used data, you'd follow this:
https://ting.com/rates
It's much simpler than I described, I think. I switched about a year ago and love them. Not for power users, though.

WRITING.TITLE: Clean while I'm away at school, but I get back to being messy once I'm back home
WRITING.TEXT: I've noticed this during my breaks at school, and summer's coming up. I'm perfectly clean while I'm in my apartment during the year. Then, when I go back home to my fiance, I have much less motivation to improve. During the year, I don't let dishes pile up, and am looking for ways to improve my surroundings. Right now I'm feeling this, about how I can't wait to get home and paint and clean out the pantry, etc. But when I actually get there, I just sit at home and be lazy. My fiance's behaviors don't help as he's much messier than I am (when he visits my apt during the year, things get messier). How do I work around that? Any reasons you guys can think of why this keeps happening?
